The President is threatening to shut down the government over funding for his senseless border wall. Congress should be working together to strengthen our military and make investments in research and education that expand economic opportunity. That's what we need-- not a border wall or a costly government shutdown.

Happy Birthday to the National Park Service. For 101 years, the legacy of NPS has preserved our nation’s most beautiful and sacred open spaces. I hope San Diegans will take time this weekend to visit Cabrillo National Monument, our own piece of history and beauty right in our backyard. #FindYourPark #MonumentsForAll

In 1920, Congress ratified the 19th amendment giving women the right to vote. This followed a long-fought, peaceful civil rights movement that began in Seneca Falls, NY at the first women’s rights convention. Today, we’re still working to expand economic and educational opportunities for women, but Women’s Equality Day reminds us we are better off for women's suffrage and all of the female elected leaders that followed.

Thank you to San Diego’s first responders on their way to help search and rescue efforts in Texas. In times of crisis, Americans will always step up to help one another. That’s who we are as a nation. It’s what makes us #USAstrong. Disasters like #HurricaneHarvey remind communities across the country that preparing for extreme weather is important. While Texas focuses on response efforts—and later, rebuilding—we should also focus on increasing our resiliency to natural disasters to prevent losing lives and the immense recovery costs of natural disasters.

12 years ago, Hurricane Katrina hit the United States and flooded almost 80 percent of New Orleans, Louisiana. Recovery took the city and its communities over a decade and Katrina is considered the worst natural disaster in U.S. history. As Hurricane Harvey continues to bring flooding, power outages and destruction to Texas, we must remember Katrina’s enduring lesson: we need to ensure communities are better prepared for extreme weather and natural disasters, which will save lives and reduce recovery costs.

Welcomed Secretary of the U.S. Navy Richard Spencer to San Diego and joined him on a tour of the USS Gabrielle Giffords. Our partnership with the U.S. Navy is essential to our national defense and our local economy. As we continue to pivot to the Pacific to counter new and dynamic threats, the demands on the Navy and on our sailors is increasing. San Diego is a proud military town and I look forward to working with Secretary Spencer to support our service members, provide them the tools they need to keep us safe, and enhance San Diego’s role in our national defense.
Hearing from San Diego seniors today to learn what issues are most important to them and to share what we’ve been working on in Congress. Follow along live to see how we’re serving San Diego.

President Trump is considering ending the DACA program, which allows immigrants brought to the United States as children to come out of the shadows and contribute to our economy. In San Diego these DREAMers are our friends and neighbors, and we are more prosperous for their contributions. I'm urging President Trump to listen to leaders from the business community and both parties and leave the program as is.
Thank you Senator Dianne Feinstein  for visiting San Diego to hear about our region’s priorities, for your independent, bipartisan approach to legislating, and for decades of service to our nation.

On this Labor Day we celebrate and thank the working men and women who continue to be the backbone of our nation’s economy, and we celebrate Labor’s early leaders who began the fight for fairer wages, safer conditions and a better workplace. Hope everyone enjoys time with friends and family today.
During these times of instability and divisiveness, we must celebrate and remember those who sacrifice and share with the most vulnerable. Eid Mubarak to all Muslims celebrating #EidAlAdha

Ending DACA is an unbelievably cruel and un-American display of cowardice from President Trump that leaves 800,000 lives in the balance and diminishes our world standing.  In San Diego, an estimated 38,000 people are currently eligible for DACA or could be in the future. They are our friends, neighbors, and co-workers who have known no other home than the United States. DACA was established because Republicans in Congress failed to even allow a vote on comprehensive immigration reform in 2013. It’s time for Congress to step up, work together and do its job to protect DREAMers. If we do nothing, we are complicit in this economic and moral catastrophe.
To #DREAMers in San Diego and across the country: I'm with you and I'll continue fighting against this hateful, misguided approach.

Testifying at the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency public hearing on fuel economy and emissions standards for cars. These standards are achievable, affordable, and offer remarkable benefits to public health and savings for American families. They shouldn’t be weakened.

Heidi from BayHo was able to work and attend UC San Diego because of the #DACA program. In 2015, Heidi graduated and found a job helping deported veterans. But today, Heidi might be forced to leave the only home she’s known because the president doesn’t understand that her contributions to San Diego’s economy and culture are valuable. Ending DACA means San Diego will lose an ally for social justice and example of what it means to be an American. #DACAStories

America is founded on the promise that if you work hard and play by the rules, then we will have a place for you. Ending DACA betrays that promise for the 800,000 Americans and 38,000 San Diegans who were brought here as young children and have been working to build a better life since then. It’s time for Congress to step up, do its job, and vote to protect DREAMers.

We can’t keep waiting for the next Hurricane Harvey or big wildfire to make communities more resilient to extreme weather. I introduced the bipartisan STRONG Act to give state and local leaders the tools and expertise to adapt approaches that have worked in other parts of the country and better prepare for disasters. This would reduce recovery costs, get people back on their feet more quickly, and in some cases, save lives.

16 years ago, we tragically lost thousands of lives in the September 11th attacks. Millions more were forever changed by the events of that day. Today, we remember everyone who died, the first responders who rushed to help their fellow Americans, and the brave service members who defended our freedom in the years that followed. The world may look like a different place today, but we will always stand united and vigilant in the face of terrorism.

Congress passed a short term spending bill that temporarily funds the government to avoid the catastrophic combination of a government shutdown and a default on our debt obligations that would devastate the economy and put Americans out of work. We did this without tying the debt ceiling to changes or cuts to Social Security and Medicare, which I oppose because these programs are lifelines for the generations that paid into them. It’s our job to keep the government open and running, but ultimately, we need a long-term budgeting process that increases community resiliency to disasters, invests in research and education to grow our economy, and supports our military leaders and business communities.

It’s an honor to nominate San Diego’s young men and women to the U.S. Service Academies. Join us for an information night to learn more about the application process and how we can help you take your first step towards a career in our military.

Joined a bipartisan group of House members at a meeting with President Trump today where I took the opportunity to convey important priorities for San Diego like protecting DREAMers, fixing our health care system, and modernizing the tax code to make businesses more competitive. I explained how San Diego’s economy depends on cross border trade and why focusing on the real challenges to border security—like using technology to screen for contraband and human trafficking—is a better approach than a wall. I haven’t been afraid to criticize the President when I disagree, but it’s still important for San Diego to have a voice in the room anytime both parties come together to discuss issues that affect our communities and economy. This was an important bipartisan conversation, but the proof will be in the results.

Over 100 workers, employers, educators, and students sent a letter to the Committee on Ways and Means in support of our bipartisan bill to help students pay down their student loan debt. As Congress begins to address tax reform, we need to consider how to reduce the burden on our graduates and our economy. It’s getting harder for students to afford the education they need to compete in today’s brain-powered economy. Working within the tax code, we can give employers flexibility to provide tuition assistance, so students have a better opportunity to buy a home, save for retirement, or start a new business after graduation—contributions that help grow our economy.

Voted against a partisan government spending bill that eliminates funding for the Border Water Infrastructure Grant Program, taking away one of our tools to prevent constant sewage spills that threaten public health and quality of life in San Diego. These grants support a bi-national partnership that helps repair sewage infrastructure that is at risk of rupturing. The bill also blocks the individual health insurance mandate, which would lead to a 15 to 20 percent premium hike, and defunds Planned Parenthood programs. It undermines our national security strategy with cuts to the Department of State and cuts NOAA’s climate change and extreme weather program as communities are still battling hurricanes and wildfires. This bill falls short in too many priorities and San Diegans and Americans deserve better.
DREAMers are our friends, our neighbors, our coworkers. They are San Diegans working toward their own American Dream. It’s time for Congress to pass the DREAM Act and protect the DACA program.

Whether he abandons or renegotiates the Paris climate accord, the president is sending a message to the rest of the world that they should look to other countries for energy innovation. This disastrous decision is just as morally wrong and monumentally stupid as it was in May. His actions won’t stop San Diego and California from doing our part to keep our air and water clean, but I hope he will reconsider and listen to the military, the private sector, our brightest minds, and nearly every other nation in the world that sees climate change as an urgent threat to our security and our economy.

Senate Republicans are making another last-ditch effort to repeal the Affordable Care Act without waiting for a non-partisan estimate of how many people will lose coverage. The #GrahamCassidy proposal might be the worst version yet: it guts protections for people with preexisting conditions, raises premiums, and destabilizes the insurance markets. California would get hammered with a $27 billion cut to MediCal that would take coverage from working families, seniors, and veterans. I’ve been working with Republicans and Democrats on healthcare solutions to keep people covered and slow the rise of premiums. We need to fix the system, not dismantle it.

A new report on the #GrahamCassidy bill found California would get hit with a $78 billion cut in federal funding, risking collapse of the individual market in the long run, which means over 4.5 million people would lose their health care. In 2027, the block grants created by the bill would run out, and Congress would need to appropriate additional funding. This misguided approach would rip health care away from millions, weaken protections for pre-existing conditions and destabilize the health insurance markets. Americans deserve quality, affordable health care—not another bill rushed through Congress with no regard for how it will affect them.
Wishing families in San Diego and across the country gathered for Rosh Hashanah a happy and healthy new year. May it bring joy, peace, and prosperity to all. L’shanah Tovah!

Visited Retrophin in Carmel Valley to learn how they’re developing therapies for people living with rare diseases, especially people who have few, if any, treatment options. Last year, Retrophin consolidated all their operations in San Diego and are continuing to grow and bring more of their products to market. Today, two-thirds of their employees are San Diego and I got to speak with them at a town hall following our visit.

Gold Star Mother’s Day is dedicated to women who lost their son or daughter in service to our country. Last Memorial Day, we helped dedicate a new plaque at Mt. Soledad honoring San Diego’s Gold Star Families. There is nothing that can repay the sacrifice of these servicemembers and their loved ones, but I hope moms in San Diego take some comfort in this tribute that honors our bravest heroes, who gave their life for our country and freedom.

Spoke with San Diego seniors to hear what issues are most important to them and share how we’re fighting for quality, affordable health care policies; supporting senior nutrition programs in the Older Americans Act; and working with the Center for Disease Control to help San Diego County mitigate the Hepatitis A outbreak.

Visited KIPP San Diego Charter School in Cortez Hill and learned about their KIPP-Through-College (KTC) program, which helps KIPP alumni prepare for college. They provide comprehensive support for KIPP students and their families beginning in middle school and by following up with students through their high school career, their college and financial application process, and also throughout their college career. We also heard from DREAMers about their educational goals and how they hope to contribute to our economy and country.
Tonight marks the beginning of Yom Kippur. Jewish communities around the world gather to pray for peace of heart and mind in the coming year.
May today's prayers provide peace of heart and mind for Jewish communities in San Diego and around the world gathered for this Day of Atonement.

Congress needs to make a bipartisan investment in the National Institutes of Health to advance life-saving treatments and research, create the jobs of the future, and protect our national security. San Diego receives more NIH research funding than any metro area in the country, and our top scientific institutions are creating jobs and growing our economy. Smart federal investments over the last thirty years helped us maintain that leadership—locally and nationally—and we need to reinvest in NIH for that to continue. The need for these investments is as urgent as ever. Read more in our op-ed for The Hill:

Shared how we’re working on issues important to San Diego with the San Diego Regional Chamber of Commerce members in town this week. When it comes to policies that are the right thing for our region and communities, the San Diego delegation excels at working together. I spoke about protecting DACA, investing in the National Institutes of Health, supporting energy innovation, and bolstering economic growth in our region. We’ll continue working to implement San Diego’s collaborative and problem-solving approach here in Congress. #SDinDC

Visited Palomar Health in Escondido to learn how their planned expansion will help meet the growing needs of North San Diego County. The current facilities uniquely use nature, light, and space to promote patient healing. It’s an example of San Diego innovation that will allow them to deliver the highest quality of clinical care and comprehensive services to patients.

59 people dead and 527 people hurt– nearly 600 people shot or injured by just one man, in just 10 minutes. These numbers are staggering, and they represent children, parents, friends, and neighbors who will never come home. They deserve to be known and mourned, and they and their families need our love and prayers. Thank you to the brave first responders who ran into danger to help save lives-- but up against 10 or more rifles, including semi-automatic weapons, there was only so much they could do. Congress, however, CAN do something: we can pass commonsense safety measures like we have in California to help lessen the chances of this happening again. Speaker Ryan has refused to let us vote yes or no on something as simple as a bipartisan bill to require universal background checks. On the contrary, Republican leadership had planned this week to let Congress consider a bill that would make it easier to purchase gun silencers without a background check. Unbelievable. We’ve sent letters, signed discharge petitions, honored gun violence victims on the House floor and met with activists at home, and I broadcast the 2016 sit-in to highlight the gun violence epidemic. We’ve done everything we can. It’s up to my Republican colleagues now to decide if they want to keep putting American lives in danger or if they are now, finally, ready to act.  We can’t prevent every random act of violence, but if we could prevent just one, it would be worth it. Mr. Speaker, I implore you, thoughts and prayers mean nothing unless they are followed by action. Let us debate gun safety and let us vote on common sense reform. And, no, it isn’t too soon to talk about this. It’s always too late.

The tragedy in Las Vegas is heartbreaking and the number of deaths and injuries is staggering. The victims deserve to be known and mourned, and they and their families need our love and prayers—but that is not enough. Will Congress finally have the courage to stand up and do something, help prevent gun violence, and keep Americans safe? I pray that my colleagues do because thoughts and prayers mean nothing unless they are followed by action. It isn’t too soon to talk about this. It’s always too late.

Helped kick off the 2018 Smart Cities Readiness Challenge with Smart Cities Council and Qualcomm to encourage cities across the country to invest in smart technology to become more livable, sustainable, and resilient. San Diego is becoming a global leader thanks to our development and deployment of Smart City technology. Our ambitious, multi-year goal is the product of the technological innovation and public-private collaboration San Diego executes so well. 2018 winners of the Readiness Challenge will also be able to build a Thinkabit Lab, which is grooming the next generation of innovators in San Diego and recently, Virginia. Best of luck to cities participating in the Challenge—San Diego can tell you, first-hand, the investment will transform your city.

After multiple failed attempts at partisan health care bills, Congress needs to come together and fund vital health programs for children and our communities. The Children's Health Insurance Program allows 9 million children across the US to access health care—including 2 million children in California. If we don’t reauthorize CHIP, the San Diego region could lose $44 million in funding. The Community Health Center program supports more than 1,200 health centers in California that provide high quality, comprehensive care to over 6 million people. Without them, people in San Diego and across the country will lose affordable, preventative care services. It’s time to stop playing politics with Americans’ health care and get to work.

#TeamPeters celebrated Manufacturing Day 2017 by visiting and learning about some of the companies and organizations that are creating jobs and driving our economy. San Diego’s manufacturing sector employs over 107,000 people across 300 diverse industries including defense, aerospace, shipbuilding, craft brewing, and active lifestyle. San Diego is one of the nation’s most important exporters of high-value manufactured goods and this ever-growing network of companies and industries adds billions of dollars to our economy. We’ll continue to support programs that address the job skills gap so San Diego’s manufacturing industry can continue to thrive.

Rolling back the Clean Power Plan takes our country backwards at a time when we should be seizing the opportunity of the clean energy revolution. This disastrous decision by the Trump Administration confirms they still don’t understand that abandoning our commitment to reducing carbon emissions also robs us of the renewable energy jobs of the future, and robs future generations of cleaner air, cleaner water, and a globally competitive economy. Eliminating the social cost of carbon will also make it harder for communities to know how carbon emissions could hurt public health and our environment. San Diego and California will continue leading the way, even in the absence of federal leadership. Going forward, we must be bolder and more decisive in pursuing the clean energy future that our children deserve.

Visited FDA headquarters to see the original research they’re doing on pandemic and endemic diseases including clinical drug trials to address health emergencies, like the Zika outbreak. At the Center for Devices and Radiological Health, we saw how they’re 3D-printing organs that can help patients get transplants faster—much like what Organovo is doing in San Diego. Computer models and simulations that are part of their larger “Innovation Initiative,” which will help better predict clinical outcomes and effectiveness.

Hispanic culture is an integral part of San Diego and southern California beginning with early roots in Barrio Logan, which is considered the epicenter of our city’s Mexican-American culture today. This year, San Diego’s Chicano Park was designated as a National Historic Landmark, a testament to the Chicano Civil Rights Movement and how that revolution shaped our Latino communities. Mexican culture has undeniably left its mark on our city―it’s on display in our neighborhoods and evident among San Diego’s people and Hispanic Heritage Month celebrates that influence. I hope you will join me in celebrating this month.

Defended energy innovation and resiliency programs during a hearing with Energy Secretary, Rick Perry. Energy experts agree improving grid efficiency and reliability require investing in energy research. ARPA-E is one energy research program that can help reduce our dependence on foreign energy sources, cut greenhouse gas emissions, and maintain U.S. leadership in the global energy sector---but the President’s budget blueprint and the Republican spending bill that passed the House in June both eliminate it. UC San Diego received $15 million in ARPA-E grants over the last five years including funding for projects to increase grid security and efficiency. Last year, Achates Power in Sorrento Valley received $9 million to develop more efficient combustion engines. Secretary Perry agreed we shouldn’t cut ARPA-E, and even suggested he would keep the program if it were up to him. I hope we can find a way to protect this important investment in energy innovation.

Pleased to announce our office is now a Vietnam War Commemorative Partner, a new way to honor veterans and surviving family members of the Vietnam War Era (November 1, 1955 - May 15, 1975) for their service and sacrifice on the 50th anniversary of the Vietnam War. As a partner, we will host events and activities to thank Vietnam-era veterans and their families. San Diego veterans or surviving family members can sign up below to be notified of our next event or ceremony.

Leading a San Diego trade mission to the UK with San Diego Regional Economic Development Corporation, World Trade Center San Diego, and local companies and organizations to establish and strengthen business and trade opportunities in the international market. The UK shares San Diego’s commitment to innovation, especially in the life sciences, smart cities technology, and urban planning, which opened new markets for San Diego: 20% of foreign investment in San Diego originates in the UK and UK companies employ 10,350 San Diegans. In today’s increasingly global economy, supporting San Diego’s role in international trade markets supports economic growth and jobs back home. Follow #SDinUK this week for more on how we're increasing collaboration across the pond. https://timesofsandiego.com/business/2017/10/12/rep-peters-lead-san-diego-trade-mission-united-kingdom/

Congrats to Dr. Walter Munk, legendary Scripps scientist and “Einstein of the Oceans." Dr. Munk and his colleagues did research that helped coordinate the successful D-Day invasion of Normandy by studying the region’s waves and calculating the safest time for our troops to land. His discovery led Scripps to open a wave-prediction school for the military and provided a foundation for the wave-casting services used by San Diego’s surfers. Dr. Munk studied how climate change affects ocean temperatures long before “climate change” was a household phrase. Dr. Munk represents the best of San Diego’s scientific innovation and problem-solving. His research improved the lives of San Diegans and people all over the world. Happy birthday and congratulations on this remarkable milestone. You have a lot to celebrate.

Back in San Diego after a successful trade mission to the United Kingdom. The relationships we forged and strengthened over this trip are important for San Diego in today’s increasingly global economy. San Diego shares many similarities with London and Cambridge, from our burgeoning life sciences sectors to smart cities technology. It was an honor to lead San Diego business and organizations as we enhanced collaboration while promoting San Diego’s key industries. I know this trip will open up new doors for San Diego and U.K. businesses alike. Check out the full recap of #SDinUK from San Diego Regional Economic Development Corporation:

Helped pass two bills to reauthorize the Customs Trade Partnership Against Terrorism (CTPAT) program and improve cargo screening technology for U.S. Customs and Border Protection. CTPAT partners work with CBP to protect the supply chain, identify security gaps, and implement specific security measures and best practices—strengthening our international supply chains and improving our border security. We also authorized funding for new screening devices, so CBP can monitor illegal drug smuggling, particularly fentanyl—a super lethal narcotic 50 times more potent than heroin and 100 times more powerful than morphine. San Diego has seen a rise in fentanyl-related deaths and these updates could help stop this highly lethal drug from entering the country.

Filipino Heritage Month celebrates the economic, cultural, and social achievements by Filipino Americans throughout U.S. history. Filipinos are the largest Asian-American population in the San Diego region, with roots dating back to 1901, when hundreds of thousands of Filipino Americans enlisted in the U.S. Navy. This October is particularly special because Congress awarded Filipino American veterans the Congressional Gold Medal—the highest civilian honor. I hope you will join me in thanking these brave heroes and celebrating Filipino Heritage Month.

Today, Congress awarded Filipino veterans of World War II the Congressional Gold Medal—the highest civilian honor. Last year, I cosponsored and helped pass the Filipino Veterans of World War II Congressional Gold Medal Act of 2015, to give Filipino American WWII veterans the recognition and benefits they earned, but never received. Almost 150,000 Filipino Americans came to San Diego after enlisting in the U.S. Navy and today, they are our largest Asian-American population. It’s an honor to recognize Filipino veterans in San Diego and across the country for their service and sacrifice to our great nation.

Voted to hold the Iranian regime accountable for destabilizing activities in the Middle East and their pursuit of ballistic missiles. From the beginning, I’ve said that while the Iran Nuclear Deal is the best way to prevent Iran from obtaining a nuclear weapon, Iran’s recent test of ballistic missiles designed to deliver nuclear weapons goes directly against the calls of the United Nations Security Council and these sanctions will help stop the supply, manufacture, and financing of harmful weapons.

Joined U.S. Environmental Protection Agency Regional Director Alexis Strauss at Industrial Environmental Association of Southern California’s conference on navigating regulatory uncertainty. Shared my perspective on how the manufacturing and business sectors can navigate federal regulations in a way that protects the environment, but also allows companies to grow knowing they’re in compliance with regulatory laws. We know we don’t have to choose between a healthy planet and a prosperous economy. Instead, we can ensure businesses are adhering to environmental regulations, but also have a level playing field.

Hosted a Grants Workshop with Congresswoman Susan Davis to provide San Diego non-profits with resources and information about applying for federal grants. Our office is here to help organizations navigate resources and guidelines to help you find and apply for the right grant. We can’t write your proposals for you, but when you apply for a grant, we can write a letter of interest to add to applications for any fully developed and qualified grant proposals. We recently wrote a letter for La Jolla-based Gaia Medical Institute, which developed a new way to diagnose Traumatic Brain Injury. They were awarded a $708,335 National Institutes of Health (NIH) grant and is currently developing those new tools right here in San Diego.  Visit our website for more information about how we can help with federal grant applications.
Visit https://www.coveredca.com/ to compare plans and #GetCovered.

Visited Aira in La Jolla, which is creating remote assist technology to help blind and visually impaired people have more independence. Their technology connects visually impaired individuals with a network of agents through “smart glasses” so they have a personal interpreter to help with daily activities and tasks. It’s one of San Diego’s startups that is creating life-changing technology through innovation that will help the more than 285 million visually impaired people worldwide.

Voted against a misguided bill that would make way for clear cutting in our forests, a logging practice that levels all the trees in an area at once. This is the wrong method for preventing forest fires and the bill also exempts these forest management practices from environmental review. Northern California just saw some of the worst wildfires in recent history, but Congress has never properly addressed the problem with wildfire disaster funding, which often needs to pull from prevention funds to deal with suppression following major wildfire disasters. Instead, we should pass the “Wildfire Disaster Funding Act,” which would allow firefighting agencies like the Forest Service to access natural disaster contingency instead of using funds set aside for prevention.

This weekend, I’m honored to join the Pontifical Academy of Sciences and Dr. Ramanathan of UC San Diego at a global climate conference in Vatican City. Addressing climate change used to be a bipartisan effort, but the divisive state of American politics has caught up to the issue. It’s evident President Trump is determined to undermine all of the progress on climate achieved by President Obama, but I will urge faith leaders to continue to use their powerful influence to change the hearts and minds of those who continue to deny that human activity is responsible for rising global temperatures.

Spoke with The San Diego Union-Tribune​ about my trip to Vatican City as part of the California delegation speaking at a global climate conference hosted by the Pontifical Academy of Sciences​. Click below for a preview of how I plan to urge my Republican colleagues to take politics out of the equation when it comes to addressing climate change. http://www.sandiegouniontribune.com/news/environment/sd-me-peters-climate-vatican-20171101-story.html

Just one month after the mass shooting in Las Vegas, our hearts are heavy again following the shooting in Sutherland Springs. We stand with Texas as they mourn the loss of family, friends, neighbors, and fellow worshipers. We also thank the brave first responders who rushed to the scene and helped save lives. This tragedy is the deadliest mass shooting in Texas history—claiming 26 lives and injuring at least 20 more. Without fully knowing the motive, this violence shakes us to the core and recalls the pain of too many instances of violence in recent history: Las Vegas, Orlando, Charleston, Newtown. No one should have to live in fear of going to school, or the movies, or church, but if we continue to let terrorists, domestic abusers, and the mentally ill purchase guns—we choose to continue enduring this burden. How many more tragedies will we have to endure before Congress finds the courage to do something? To Speaker Ryan and my Republican colleagues, I implore you—once again—thoughts and prayers mean nothing unless they are followed by action. Let us debate and vote on common sense gun reform before it’s once again, too late.

Veterans Day is a time to thank the heroes who bravely put country before self. It’s also a time for Congress to do its part to keep its promise to have veterans’ backs when they come home. In what is an increasingly hostile and partisan environment, the House Committee on Veterans' Affairs stands apart as a place where Democrats and Republicans come together to do right by our veterans. This year, we addressed the appeals backlog at the Veterans Benefits Administration and passed the most sweeping reforms to strengthen veteran education benefits in a decade. This week, we will build on that progress and continue to keep our commitment to veterans by improving and protecting the benefits they earned through their service. I’ll be highlighting some of these bills every day this week.  Today, I helped pass a bill that guards veterans against predatory businesses. It directs the VA to warn veterans of businesses that convince veterans to pay for help with their benefit claims. These services are actually free, and available to San Diego veterans through my office. It’s just one way we can serve them, just as they served us.

Helped pass four bills to improve quality and access to care health care for veterans. The Veteran Urgent Access to Mental Healthcare Act will increase access to mental health care by extending coverage to former servicemembers who might not otherwise qualify due to their discharge status. The Veterans Transplant Coverage Act will allow the VA to perform organ donation and transplant procedures. The VICTOR Act will allow veterans to receive organ and bone marrow transplants outside of VA facilities to increase access for veterans on Medicare. The VETS Act of 2017 will allow VA doctors to use telemedicine across state lines, giving veterans more choice in health care providers. For everything our veterans gave in service to our country, they earned timely, quality health care that works for them.  Mental Health Care Act : http://bit.ly/2jb9OKO Transplant Coverage Act : http://bit.ly/2yj1Ba5 VICTOR Act : http://bit.ly/2zHFcYD VETS Act : http://bit.ly/2hUcnxw

When our heroes return home, finding housing shouldn't be a difficult process. I helped pass the SERVE Act, which directs the VA to make documentation of Basic Housing Allowance available online. This would make it easier for veterans to apply for and find housing since they will be able to easily provide proof of income. This bill is one way we can ensure veterans have basic needs covered during their transition to civilian life.

Every year, more than 20,000 sailors and marines stationed in San Diego leave military service and roughly a third choose to stay. Since 2015, zero8hundred has provided one on one counseling, referrals, and guidance for our servicemembers before, during, and after their transition to civilian life. In just over two years, the program expanded to six bases, and on-base transition classes have been presented to over 20,000 active-duty sailors and marines. It is my hope that zero8hundred becomes a national model for helping our veterans and their families. More in our op-ed in The Hill:

Today, we launched our new partnership with  The United States of America Vietnam War Commemoration, a new program to honor Vietnam-era veterans, their families, and organizations that contributed to the war effort on the home front. Unfortunately, many Vietnam veterans were not treated with the respect they deserved when they returned home, and this program aims to properly honor their service and sacrifice. As a Commemorative Partner, my office will host events and ceremonies for veterans and their families. Learn more about the Commemorative Partnership and sign up to be notified of future events: https://scottpeters.house.gov/vietnam-war-commemorative-partner-0

Happy Birthday to Malin Burnham: San Diegan, philanthropist, and champion sailor. His personal mantra of “Community Before Self” is evident in his lasting contributions to San Diego from the 14 non-profits he founded to Sanford Burnham Prebys Medical Discovery Institute, which saves an estimated one million lives a year through their groundbreaking research. Have a great day and happy birthday, Malin. You’ve certainly earned it.
Happy Veterans Day, San Diego. Thank you to the men and women who bravely served our great nation. Today, we salute you.

It was an honor to spend Veterans Day at two monuments to our nation’s heroes here in San Diego— Mount Soledad and  Miramar National Cemetery. In San Diego, celebrating our heroes isn’t limited to just one day, but Veterans Day is a time to reflect on how we can better serve them. It’s difficult to serve veterans in the same way they so honorably served us—but we certainly owe it to them to try. When they return from service we need to ensure they can get a job or pursue higher education, have access to quality health care, and that those struggling with mental health or homelessness are supported and helped. San Diego continues to be a model for veterans organizations across the nation and in Congress, we’ll continue to break partisan barriers and put the care of our nation’s 21 million veterans above all else.

The final defense policy bill passed by Congress further expands the military’s investment in San Diego, bolsters energy security innovation, and includes a pay raise for our servicemembers. The bill funds construction projects at Navy Special Warfare on Coronado and MCAS Miramar and boosts U.S. Navy and U.S. Marine Corps shipbuilding, which will help close readiness gaps that constrain military operations and endanger the lives of our service members. It’s encouraging this latest act of Congress gives the U.S. Department of Defense (DoD) autonomy to pursue its energy security goals and prepare for the threat of climate change. I just advocated for government action on climate at the global workshop hosted by the Pontifical Academy of Sciences and I hope Congress continues to listen to our military leaders, who understand investing in renewable energy is a smart approach.

Voted no on the GOP plan to raise taxes on hardworking Californians and add $1.5 trillion dollars to our already high national debt. The cost of this bill will likely exceed the size of our economy by 2028 and lead to less private investment, higher interest rates, and slower wage growth. It eliminates state and local tax deductions, which save California taxpayers an average of $18,438 and generates funds that state and local governments use for public improvement projects like schools, law enforcement, and infrastructure. California homebuyers will qualify for lower deductions on mortgage loans and our affordable housing sector took a huge hit in funding.  The long-term economic consequences of this bill will hurt our economy and American families. We need real, fiscally responsible tax reform, but the tax bill that passed today shifts a huge unpaid burden of debt to our children. History has shown that the only path to successful tax reform is bipartisanship and I sincerely hope the Senate does better than we did today.

The House Judiciary Committee passed our bipartisan bill with Congressman Darell Issa to raise the eligibility requirements for H1B visa exemptions, level the playing field, and help prevent companies from abusing the system to outsource jobs. The bill will protect American jobs by ensuring these visas are only available to the best and the brightest in the world. At the same time, American innovators can access the talent they need to maintain a competitive workforce.

Celebrated some of our newest citizens at a U.S. Citizenship and Immigration Services Children’s Citizenship Ceremony. These children represent the next generation and our country’s future success. We are a nation of immigrants, built on the promise that everyone, through hard work, has a fair shot at building a better life. That spirit is in each of these children as they begin their journey as citizens. Congratulations.

Small Business Saturday celebrates small businesses who help grow our economy and provide more opportunities for consumers to purchase goods and services. In San Diego, we know a commitment to supporting entrepreneurs and startups is essential to economic progress and creating jobs. #ShopSmall

Matrix Sensors in Sorrento Valley just received a $1,530,000 Advanced Research Projects Agency - Energy (ARPA-E) grant to develop a low-cost CO2 sensor module for commercial building ventilation. The project is part of a new ARPA-E program to develop technologies that can reduce the energy used to heat and cool buildings by 30%. ARPA-E has provided $1.5 billion to over 580 projects since it was created in 2009, but the President's budget blueprint and Republican spending bill both eliminated this program. I've advocated for ARPA-E because of these grants are vital to San Diego’s innovation economy and American leadership in energy innovation.
Happy Thanksgiving, San Diego. I’m thankful and honored to represent you in Congress. I hope everyone enjoys celebrating with family, friends, and loved ones.

In order to maintain a truly free, fair, and open internet, strong net neutrality protections must be put in place. The plan unveiled today by Federal Communications Commission Chairman Ajit Pai undermines essential components of current net neutrality rules that level the playing field for consumers and small businesses. These protections should not be subject to the whims of one administration to the next. Congress must act to provide a legislative solution to make these protections strong, reliable, and permanent.

Yesterday, we passed the Law Enforcement Mental Health and Wellness Act which recognizes and helps address the high level of occupational stress police officers face while on the job. Regular stress and traumatic situations can lead to alcohol abuse, heart disease, family problems, and suicide. The bill expands the use of grant funds under the Community Oriented Policing Services (COPS) to create health and wellness pilot programs in state and local enforcement agencies, which will help our law enforcement officers be better first responders. The Department of Justice will be required to work with Health and Human Services to create educational resources for mental health providers specifically tailored to helping law enforcement.   Law Enforcement Mental Health and Wellness Act: http://bit.ly/2nd6iRD

Finally, Congress mandated anti-harassment training for all offices in the House of Representatives. Ever since being elected to Congress, all of my staff, including me, have been required to complete this training simply because it was the right thing to do. The action today is only the first step. Next, we must change the ridiculous law that allows members to use taxpayer money to pay for settlements in sexual harassment cases. Congress must set the example with a respectful work environment and zero tolerance policy toward all forms of harassment, discrimination, and abuse.  https://scottpeters.house.gov/media-center/press-releases/rep-peters-praises-overdue-anti-harassment-training-mandate

Spoke on the floor of the U.S. House of Representatives this morning to deliver a strong rebuke of the GOP Tax Plan that will balloon the national deficit by $1.5 trillion, fails to give real tax relief to American families who need it most, and will not boost economic growth for our nation. It’s time to put country before partisan politics and for Congress to work together toward real, fiscally responsible tax reform.

Today, I stood side by side with my colleagues to pass a bipartisan resolution, which condemns in the harshest terms the ethnic cleansing of Rohingya Muslims by the Burmese Government. Since August 25, attacks attributed to Burma’s military and private mobs have resulted in the displacement of over 600,000 Rohingya to neighboring Bangladesh. We must stand up for marginalized communities all around the world and protect people’s right to pray freely without the fear of attack from their own government. I hope the Government of Burma will heed our call and immediately end the current onslaught.  http://bit.ly/2zVOixf

Thinking of our neighbors to the north affected by the Ventura and San Bernardino county wildfires that have already covered over 71,000 acres and destroyed more than 150 structures. San Diego is on high alert as fires continue to burn through these parts of Los Angeles.

Voted no on a bill that would undermine California’s common-sense gun safety laws. If signed into law, the concealed carry standard passed today will dramatically weaken states’ ability to protect their communities from gun violence. Today’s action to weaken this standard wrongly was combined with a bill that would have strengthened the nation’s background checks. The Fix NICS Act addresses the need to strengthen our National Instant Criminal Background Check System (NICS), which is used to ensure that only low-risk individuals are able to purchase firearms. I strongly support fixing NICS, but I cannot support a bill that weakens California gun safety laws. The decision to combine concealed carry reciprocity to the Fix NICS Act is the equivalent to taking one step forward and then seven steps back. America is suffering from a gun violence epidemic and I’m tired of Congress refusing to stand up to the gun lobby to protect the American people from senseless gun violence.

Today is the 76th anniversary of the devastating attack on Pearl Harbor that led to World War II. Let us never forget the brave men and women who lost their lives that tragic day. We must also remember the survivors and those who fought in World War II to protect the freedoms we cherish today. December 7th, 1941 will always be “a date which will live in infamy.”   https://www.nbcsandiego.com/news/national-international/Nation-Observes-76th-Anniversary-of-Attack-on-Pearl-Harbor-462531193.html

Today, I defended the EPA methane rule in a hearing with U.S. Environmental Protection Agency Administrator Scott Pruitt. Pruitt refused to answer how he would like methane to be regulated and did not commit to whether or not the agency would be making any substantive changes to the methane rule. I support the rule because it will boost energy supplies, reduce air pollution, air toxins, and greenhouse gases. The estimated benefit of capturing methane emissions from the oil and gas industry is $2 billion dollars annually. I’m proud that California has adopted strong rules aimed at reducing methane emissions.

Helped pass the Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency Act, which consolidates our nation’s cybersecurity efforts into the Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA). CISA will have three different divisions – cybersecurity, infrastructure security, and emergency communications. These divisions will be responsible for coordinating with other government agencies and securing information systems and operational policies. This bill strengthens our defense against the ever-expanding threat that cyber threats pose to the United States.

Happy Hanukkah to San Diego families gathered together tonight. The Festival of Lights reminds us that in darkness, together we have enough light to get through even the toughest times. Wishing a blessed celebration spent with families and friends.

Yesterday, I spoke on the floor of the U.S. House of Representatives to support a bill to give hydropower projects an expedited process for approval from the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission. Closed-loop pumped storage hydropower projects generate power from reservoirs using elevation change. In San Diego, where large rivers and typical hydropower generation are less common, closed-loop pumped storage hydropower offers an innovative solution. Generating more electricity from hydropower projects is key to meeting our clean energy goals and battling climate change. We must continue to pass productive, bipartisan bills like these that streamline the regulatory process so hydropower projects can be approved more quickly while still meeting high environmental standards.

Yesterday, I helped pass resolutions to reaffirm our country’s economic and strategic partnerships with Mexico and Canada, which are essential to our trade economy, counterterrorism efforts, and border security. San Diego’s top two export markets are Mexico and Canada, which generate $5.5 billion in annual exports and support roughly 120,000 jobs here at home. These resolutions are the basis for mutually beneficial trade agreements. Going forward, the U.S. should prioritize raising enforceable environmental and labor standards, especially given the sewage spill that is still flowing into San Diego waterways.

Five years ago, twenty six lives were tragically cut short during the shooting at Sandy Hook Elementary School.  I was elected to Congress just weeks before this tragedy, but here we are—years later—and Congress has still not acted to reduce gun violence. These victims deserve to be known and remembered, but the best way we can honor them is with action. Their memory is what drives our fight to address gun violence and I won’t stop fighting until my colleagues in Congress find the courage to do something before it’s once again, too late.

Yesterday, San Diego lost one of its heroes. I am deeply saddened to learn Cory Iverson died while battling the Thomas Fire. Our most heartfelt condolences go out to Cory’s family, friends, and loved ones. Our first responders make tremendous sacrifices to keep us all safe, putting our well-being above their own. Thank you to all the brave men and women continuing to battle wildfires across California. Please be safe.

Joined Miramar National Cemetery for Wreaths Across America. Every December, thousands of wreaths are placed in cemeteries across the country to honor our fallen servicemen and women. Traditionally, volunteers take a moment to say the veteran’s name out loud and thank them for their service to our country—a way to keep each veteran’s memory alive. December is also a time to remember our troops serving abroad, who are away from their families and loved ones for the holidays.Thanks to all in San Diego and across the world for your service.

Helped pass four bills to increase investment in STEM education, including expanding opportunities for women and veterans. The first bill encourages public-private partnerships to bring computer science education to K-12 classrooms. The others require the National Science Foundation to encourage women and minorities to pursue STEM programs. NSF would prioritize females fellows and veterans pursuing STEM careers to reduce barriers for entering STEM fields. Investing in STEM training helps equip our workforce with the skills they need to compete in our increasingly global economy.

Helped pass the Jobs for Our Heroes Act to make it easier for veterans to get a job in the truck driving industry. The bill expands the list of VA medical professionals who can sign off on exams needed for veterans to get a commercial driver’s license if they can prove they received the training in the military. It’s another way we can ensure veterans can get a job using the skills they learned during their service.

Congress pushed through another tax bill--in a complete failure of the legislative process--that will add roughly $2 trillion dollars to our already high national debt and raise taxes on Californians. The bill particularly hurts California by capping both the state and local tax deduction and mortgage interest rate deduction. California households claim an average state and local tax deduction of $18,400, but the bill imposes a $10,000 cap. The bill also caps mortgage interest deductions at $750,000, but 8.2% of new mortgage loans in San Diego exceeded that amount last year. This anti-growth bill fails to deliver for hardworking San Diegans thanks to another rushed, partisan process. In the 1980s, Congress worked for two years on a bipartisan tax bill calling for a revenue-neutral, pro-growth plan and I’ve called for a similarly open and bipartisan process. I stand ready to work with my colleagues on real reforms when they realize the consequences of this rushed, partisan bill.

Helped pass the RAISE #FamilyCaregiversAct, to better support the estimated 40 million unpaid family caregivers in the U.S. Family members are often the first and best caregivers, who take on the responsibility without formal guidance or support, Affecting their own lives and finances. The bill will help caregivers by creating a Family Caregiving Advisory Council, tasked with establishing a national strategy focused on promoting family-centered care, training, education and financial security.
From my family to yours—Merry Christmas, San Diego.

2017 has been quite a year. At the start, I promised I would be guided by the principles of loyalty, truth, opportunity for all, strength abroad, and kindness. We saw some heartbreaking headlines across the country and the globe, but San Diego—its people, innovation, and accomplishments—is what grounds our mission. It’s been an honor to work on behalf San Diegans this year. Looking forward to doing the same in 2018.
